docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
Structured Query Language (SQL for short) is a language that can be used to create and communicate with a database.

We use SQL to retrieve data from a table we use a special method called a QUERY.

A query will retrieve some data from the database table based on a question or need.

docs.title: Select From
docs.text:
Display all data from a table
SELECT * 
FROM "table_name"
Display specific columns from table
SELECT "column_name" 
FROM table_name
Displays two columns from a table
SELECT "column_name", "column_name" 
FROM "table_name"

docs.title: Select From Where
docs.text:
Display Data IF it is EQUAL to Required Data

SELECT * 
FROM "table_name"
WHERE Column = Required Term
Display Data IF it is > than Required Data
SELECT * 
FROM "table_name"
WHERE Column > Required Term

docs.title: Databases and SQL Assessment
docs.text: Duration: 1 hour 50 minutes

docs.title: Learning Outcomes
docs.text:
By completing this assessment, pupils will demonstrate their ability to:

  1. Create a database with an appropriate table structure

  2. Use SQL to retrieve and manipulate data in response to given scenarios

  3. Apply problem-solving skills to analyze and process data effectively

docs.title: Assessment Instructions
docs.text:
You are required to:

  1. Part A: Design and create a single table to store and manage information.

  2. Part B: Write SQL queries to interact with the database.

docs.title: Scenario
docs.text: You are working for a local library that needs a database to keep track of its books.

docs.title: Part A: Database Design and Creation (40 marks)
docs.text:
1. Identify Table Fields (5 marks)

  2. Create a single table called Books with the following fields:

    • Book ID (Primary Key)
    • Title
    • Author
    • Genre
    • Published Year
    • Price
    • Stock Quantity

  3. Define the Table Structure (10 marks)

  4. Choose appropriate data types for each field:

    • For example, Book ID should be an integer, and Title should be text.

  5. Create the Table (10 marks)

  6. Use a database management tool to create the table with the specified structure.

  7. Populate the Table with Data (15 marks)

  8. Add at least 10 records of books, ensuring data is realistic and varied.

docs.title: Part B: SQL Query Questions (60 marks)
Task 1: Retrieve Data (20 marks)
docs.text:
Write SQL queries to answer the following:

  1. List all books in the "Science Fiction" genre. (5 marks)

  2. Display the titles and authors of all books published before the year 2000. (5 marks)

  3. Show the title, genre, and price of all books that cost more than £10. (5 marks)

  4. Find all books written by "George Orwell". (5 marks)

docs.title: Task 2: Sorting Data (20 marks)
docs.text:
Write SQL queries to answer the following:

  1. Display all books in alphabetical order by their title. (5 marks)

  2. Retrieve the details of all books in the "Fiction" genre, sorted by their publication year (oldest to newest). (5 marks)

  3. List the titles and authors of all books priced between £5 and £10 from low to high. (5 marks)

  4. Sort all books by their price in descending order and display the title, price, and stock quantity. (5 marks)

docs.title: Task 3: Analyse Data (20 marks)
docs.text:
Write SQL queries to answer the following:

  1. Retrieve the titles and genres of books published before 1950. (5 marks)

  2. Display the titles of all books that cost exactly £8.49. (5 marks)

  3. List the titles and prices of books with a stock quantity greater than or equal to 10. (5 marks)

  4. Find all books with a stock quantity of less than 10. (5 marks)

docs.title: Part A: Database Design and Creation (40 marks)
docs.text: Task Marks Criteria Identify Table Fields 5 Fields align with the requirements of the scenario. Define the Table Structure 10 Correctly assigns appropriate data types for each field. Create the Table 10 Successfully creates the table with no errors. Populate the Table 15 Inserts realistic and varied data for all 10 records.

docs.title: Part B: SQL Query Questions (60 marks)
docs.text: Task Marks Criteria Retrieve Data 20 Queries return the correct results and use appropriate syntax. Sorting Data 20 Queries successfully order data as required. Analyse Data 20 Queries accurately calculate or identify data based on requirements.

When the left and right broadcasts are received, the hills sprite should move. To give the appearance of moving in the correct direction, the background moves left when the rover is moving right. The direction of motion should be opposite to the broadcast.

So, if the broadcast is left, then the x position will increase. If the broadcast is right, then the x of the hills will decrease.

To make it look like the rover is moving left and right, the background will scroll instead of the rover moving.

To fix this, the sprite and its clone need to be moved to the other side of the screen when they go too far.

Create a new broadcast called scroll and add the block to the start script.

Test: Click the green flag to reset the scene and then use the controller or arrow keys to move the rover.

The background should scroll, and the rover should never reach the end.
